facts.text: Notices have been issued to the petitioners under section 6 of the Tamil Nadu Land Encroachment Act, 1905 in order to evict them from a certain piece of land claimed to be Government land.
The challenge to the constitutional validity of the Tamil Nadu Land Encroachment Act, 1905 is based solely on the decision of this Court in Northern India Caterers v. Punjab (1967) 3 SCR 399.

In Northern India Caterers case, the State had leased premises to the appellant for running a hotel; lease expired; appellant failed to vacate; Collector issued notice under S.4 of Punjab Act requiring show cause why eviction order under S.5 should not be passed.
Section 2 of the Tamil Nadu Act defines property of Government extensively, including public roads, waters, lands except certain specified properties.
Section 3: Unauthorized occupier liable to pay full assessment.
Section 6: Provides for eviction, forfeiture of crops, buildings; eviction by notice under S.7 after reasonable time; summary inquiry if resistance; appeal and revision provisions.
Section 14: Right of suit for aggrieved person.
On behalf of petitioners, contended that they were still in possession.
On behalf of State, contended that three of the petitioners had been evicted even before this Court passed an order of stay.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Tamil Nadu Land Encroachment Act, 1905 is unconstitutional and void, violating Article 14, as it provides an additional drastic remedy over ordinary suit procedure, similar to the Punjab Act in Northern India Caterers case.

petitioner_arguments.text: The Act confers an additional remedy over and above the remedy by way of suit and thereby violates Art. 14 by providing two alternative remedies to the Government and leaving it to the unguided discretion of the Collector to resort to one or the other.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Northern India Caterers v. Punjab (1967) 3 SCR 399

respondent_arguments.text: Three of the petitioners had been evicted even before this Court passed an order of stay.

court_reasoning.text: The decision in Maganlal Chhagganlal (P) Ltd. v. Municipal Corporation of Greater Bombay (1975) 1 SCR 1 applies on all fours; it upheld similar eviction acts against Art. 14 challenge by disagreeing with Northern India Caterers majority.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mere availability of two procedures (suit or special act) does not vitiate the special procedure; sufficient guidance in object to evict unauthorized occupants speedily.

court_reasoning.text: Principles from precedents: Statute providing drastic procedure without guidelines hit by Art. 14 unless guidelines inferred or covers specific class; appeal may cure; normal behavior assumes use of speedy procedure.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Officers expected to use special procedure, not ordinary court; discrimination improbable.

court_reasoning.text: Procedures in TN Act and similar acts not so harsh: notice, show cause, representation, inquiry powers like civil court, appeal to judicial officer, further High Court remedies under Art. 226/227.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Difference between procedures not unconscionable; Art. 14 does not demand fanatical approach.

holdings.text: Tamil Nadu Land Encroachment Act, 1905 not hit by Art. 14 of the Constitution.

precedents_cited.relevance: Petitioners' basis for challenge; majority held Punjab Act violates Art. 14; court disagrees with majority.

precedents_cited.case_name: Maganlal Chhagganlal (P) Ltd. etc. v. Municipal Corporation of Greater Bombay Ors. etc.
precedents_cited.relevance: Upholds Chapter V-A Bombay Municipal Corporation Act and Bombay Government Premises Eviction Act against Art. 14; applies directly.
Drastic procedure without guidelines violates Art. 14.
Appeal may cure defect; guidelines from preamble etc.
Statute covering class of cases valid.
Statute covering class of cases valid.

outcome.summary: The writ petitions challenging the constitutional validity of the Tamil Nadu Land Encroachment Act, 1905 are dismissed, following the reasoning in Maganlal Chhagganlal case that such special eviction procedures do not violate Art. 14.

key_quotes.text: We, therefore, find ourselves unable to agree with the majority in the Northern India Caterers case.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Court expressly disagrees with the precedent relied on by petitioners.

key_quotes.text: Art. 14 does not demand a fanatical approach.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies upholding special procedures despite differences from ordinary law.

key_quotes.text: This decision would apply on all fours to the facts of the present case.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Directly applies Maganlal to uphold TN Act.
